Observation: I tested several groups of gridsize and iteration times using
both parallel and sequential methods, the results are exactly the same.

/***************************************
best speedup report:
eris:~/cse475/p2% ./p2 -g 1026
name, seed, gridsize, verbose, iters
no_name, 0, 1026, 0, 1024
Sequential: 11907055122 (ns)
Parallel: 3116318479 (ns)
speedup: 3.82

eris:~/cse475/p2% ./p2 -g 514
name, seed, gridsize, verbose, iters
no_name, 0, 514, 0, 1024
Sequential: 3383622994 (ns)
Parallel: 790379472 (ns)
speedup: 4.28

eris:~/cse475/p2% ./p2 -g 130
name, seed, gridsize, verbose, iters
no_name, 0, 130, 0, 1024
Sequential: 236329156 (ns)
Parallel: 56341993 (ns)
speedup: 4.19

eris:~/cse475/p2% ./p2 -g 258
name, seed, gridsize, verbose, iters
no_name, 0, 258, 0, 1024
Sequential: 857904623 (ns)
Parallel: 202229578 (ns)
speedup: 4.24

eris:~/cse475/p2% ./p2 -g 66 
name, seed, gridsize, verbose, iters
no_name, 0, 66, 0, 1024
Sequential: 65942187 (ns)
Parallel: 19811727 (ns)
speedup: 3.33

The best speed up is 4.28 when gridsize is around 514. The result can be seen by running test.sh.
I used parallel_for and changed grainsize to see if it has an obvious influence
on speedup of parallelism. My observation is that too small(e.g. smaller than 66) or too large gridsize(e.g. larger than 1026)
both have reduced the speedup of parallel computing(ratio reduces from 4 to 3).
When the size of ocean dataset is small, parallel computing does not show much
advantage than the sequential one. In order to find out the influence of
grainsize, I changed the grainsize from gridsize/4 to
gridsize*16 and found out that grainsize around gridsize/2 has the best
speedup. This means that too small grainsize will improve overhead or
multi-threads while too large grainsize will make each thread have heavy load.
In theory, grainsize of 2^n+2 makes best balance among threads.
